block.p: FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''AESOP'S FABLES,'' presented by the Vital Children's Theater Company. The young actresses and the director Bruce Merrill, who collaborated on the script, have filled it with references to current pop figures as well as with characters accessible to 3- to 10-year-olds. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. Vital Children's Theater Company, 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 592-4508.

''BUTTERFLY'S ADVENTURE: A LEPIDOPTERA OPERA,'' a musical theater piece by the Amazing Landfill Gardeners of Gondwanaland, featuring a caterpillar that changes into a butterfly, a talking tree, birds and a moth, Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Children's Museum of the Arts, 182 Lafayette Street, SoHo. Free with admission: $5. Information: (212) 274-0986.

''CHARLOTTE'S WEBB,'' E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider, adapted by Joseph Robinette. Presented by the Pied Piper Children's Theater, children ages 5 to 14 who are involved in all aspects of the production. Performances are tomorrow and Sunday (and May 13) at 3 at 7 p.m. at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 20 Cumming Street, Inwood. Tickets: $16; $3 for children under 18. Information: (212) 567-2329.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed in Spanish and English simultaneously), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the familiar story but with a twist. Little Red does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to question his identity. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Through June 25. Los Kabayitos Theater, 107 Suffolk Street, second floor, Lower East Side. Tickets: $8; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''KINGDOM OF THE SUN,'' directed by Zac Whinnem, is knights and courtiers, Monty Python style. Josh Cagan's play is also a feminist fairy tale in which the king's female page, Harold, saves him. Sundays through May 21 at 2 p.m. Manhattan Theater Source, 177 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.

''PIRATES OF PENZANCE,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta about a band of pirates and their adventures, performed by the West Side Y.M.C.A.'s Kids Company, youngsters trained in musical theater who perform for other children. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7; Sunday at 2 p.m. 5 West 63rd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 875-4277.
Events

CARIBBEAN CARNIVAL, tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the New York Aquarium, West Eighth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn. Children will view Caribbean wildlife like coral, dolphins and turtles while enjoying music, mask making, arts and crafts, and other activities with a Caribbean flavor. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $9.75; children 2 to 12 and the elderly, $6; under 2, free. Information: (718) 265-3474.

CELEBRATE MAY at the Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton, Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., with activities, crafts and a Maypole. Free with zoo admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Information: (718) 442-3101 or (718) 442-3174.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVATORY Workshops, tomorrow from 1 to 4 p.m at the Henry Luce Nature Observatory at Belvedere Castle, midpark at 79th Street. ''Hawk Navigation and Migration,'' with educators from the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, who will introduce youngsters to these birds, also known as raptors. ''Tiles That Bring Smiles'' gives youngsters 6 and older an opportunity to explore the history of the Minton tiles on the ceiling of the Bethesda Arcade, installed in the 1870's, and then design and put together their own tiles. Free, but reservations required: (212) 772-0210.

''THE CINDERELLA MAGIC SHOW'' combines illusion with live animals and participation from the audience. The creator, Arnie Kolodner, has added comic touches to the familiar story, with Cinderella, played by Alice Bergmann, driving her own pumpkin. St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 East 76th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11 a.m., 1:30 p.m. and 4 p.m. Tickets: $17.50. Information: (212) 279-4200.

''CIRCUS TO GO,'' a workshop featuring clowns, presented by the Big Apple Circus tomorrow at two Queens sites: at 1 p.m. at the Flushing Library, 41-17 Main Street, (718) 661-1212; at 4:30 p.m., Kew Gardens Hills Branch, 72-33 Vleigh Place, (718) 261-6654. Free.

COLUMBIA GREENHOUSE SPRING FAIR, tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. (rain date is Sunday), will bring a minifarm to the sidewalks of Morningside Heights, on 116th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive. The Greenhouse is an 80-year-old nursery school affiliated with Columbia University. Free events include a petting zoo, a firetruck for climbing, a carousel, pony rides and face painting. Information: (212) 666-4796.

''PEONY FESTIVAL'' coincides with the Chinese Peony Show in the Haupt Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx, in which the colorful blossoms of the Chinese tree peony are in bloom. Featured activities, today through May 14 include hands-on activities, storytellers telling Chinese folk tales and a Chinese lion dance. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Everett Children's Adventure Garden hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Parking: $5. A ''garden passport'' combination ticket grants admission to the entire grounds, with a tram tour: adults, $10; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.

''STUART DAVIS IN GLOUCESTER.'' A tour of the landscapes of the Cape Ann community of Gloucester by Stuart Davis at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 90th Street, will be the starting point of a family program for children and an accompanying adult tomorrow from 2 to 3 p.m. After viewing images of the picturesque harbors, shipyards, hillsides and street scenes, visitors will create postcards with the artist Hannah Frassinelli. They can also bring some from home to collage into their creations. Fee: $6 for children 5 to 12 and accompanying adults. Reservations: (212) 369-4880, extension 244.

''SUBWAYS, SEA CREATURES, TOOLS AND TEA.'' At first it may be hard to see what these items have in common. The connection will be revealed tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Tanishka Kachru, a decorative arts intern, will talk about the manufacture, decoration and use of silver objects over the last 300 years. Free with suggested museum admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.

''UNIVERSAL HAIR PUPPET MAKING WORKSHOP.'' ''Hair in African Art and Culture,'' an exhibition through May 28 at the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, in SoHo, is the inspiration for a workshop tomorrow at 1 p.m. for ages 5 and older. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for students, children and the elderly; free on Sundays. Information: (212) 966-1313.

''WELCOME,'' a new exhibition opening Sunday at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, presents work by 11 artists exploring ideas of home and the relationship between people and nature. The new exhibition (through Aug. 20) will be celebrated with activities, programs and tours from 1 to 4 p.m. Events include a performance by Skip LaPlante and his ensemble, who perform on instruments made from household items, and a chance to create a Chinese landscape painting. Free buses to and from midtown Manhattan; for bus reservations: (718) 549-3200, extension 248. Grounds hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.

MEADOWFAIR at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, Sunday from noon to 5 p.m. The museum's annual spring celebration features crafts, workshops and entertainment. Admission: children, $8; adults, $5. Also tomorrow, from 1 to 4 p.m., youngsters can learn how to combine water, oil, food dye and their imaginations to create water sculptures. Fee: $2 plus museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Information: (718) 273-2060.

''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: THE CHINESE BRUSH.'' Stories about a magic brush that makes anything it paints come to life will be the subject of stories told by the educator Angie Kim, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the Chinese Galleries, second floor, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''THREE OLD MEN WHO WANT TO LIVE FOREVER,'' an opera created for 5- to 12-year-olds, will be presented tomorrow at noon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Created by Josee Hussaarts and Suzanne van Lohuizen and performed by three singing actors from the Netherlands, the fairy tale introduces the concept of aging and mortality. Although it begins with three old men who wake up one morning to learn they are going to die, the program includes jokes, singing, dancing and games as it goes about its message of acceptance and unexpected new beginnings. Tickets: $10.
